properties.General Description: The remains of the archaeological site of Siraf stretch over 0.5-1km along a narrow coastal strip. In the 9-10th c AD, Siraf was at its greatest extent. The site was initially occupied in the Sasanian period. Medieival Siraf however is more represented archaeologically.

properties.Effect Type: Surface Loss, Artefact Displacement, Alteration of Terrain, Loss/Removal of Archaeological Material
properties.General Description:
Laft I (QS 133) is located directly on the coast some
4 km east of Bandar-e Laft. With dimensions of c.
680 × 480 m, it is one of the largest historic period sites
ever recorded on Qeshm Island. Although the surface finds indicate the site was occupied in Sasanian to Seljuq
times, a total of 20 Bronze Age pottery sherds were also
recorded across its surface. Survey results in  Khosrowzadeh et al. (2017)
properties.Threat Category: Natural, Looting/Illegal Activities, Building and Development
properties.Threat Inference Making Assessor Name -: Crystal Safadi, Crystal Safadi, Crystal Safadi

properties.Effect Type: Artefact Displacement, Loss/Removal of Archaeological Material, Earth Displacement, Covered
properties.General Description:
Cemetery located 1 km south of village Zeinabi. Location of site is not exact, it is situated on  a relatively elevated, eroded rocky hill composed
predominantly of sandstone with a marl bed.
Zeinabi IV consists of more than 20 small tumuli
that have been disturbed either naturally or anthropogenically. See Khosrowzadeh et al. (2017)

properties.Effect Type: Artefact Displacement, Loss/Removal of Archaeological Material, Earth Displacement, Covered
properties.General Description:
The cemetery labelled Zeinabi V (QS 104) comprises
seven small grave tumuli on a rocky hill. Although the stone structures of the
graves have been significantly destroyed, a few tumuli
have remained relatively intact and survive to a height
of c.2 m. See Khosrowzadeh et al. (2017)

. The hill itself is heavily eroding marl.Several relatively well-preserved stone tumuli are the most noticeable feature

properties.General Description:
It is
located in the flat and even terrain of the Turian plain
and extends over an area c. 180 × 580 m.The
main surface characteristic of the site is the ubiquitous
distribution of seashells, alongside a relatively high density
of potsherds. See Khosrowzadeh et al. (2017)

properties.General Description:
This site is composed of a series of
large and small mounds up to 2 m in height. The main feature of this site is again the ubiquity of seashells, and
the remains of sandstone and mud mortar construction
could be traced on most parts of the mound. See Khosrowzadeh et al. (2017)
